heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.2. The GetRequest-PDU
sentence: The value of the request-id field of the GetResponse-PDU is that of the received GetRequest-PDU message.
enhanced_sentence: When generating a GetResponse-PDU in response to a received GetRequest-PDU, regardless of whether the response indicates success (noError) or any error condition (noSuchName, tooBig, genErr), the receiving protocol entity must copy the exact value from the request-id field of the original GetRequest-PDU into the request-id field of the corresponding GetResponse-PDU. This ensures proper request-response correlation between the SNMP manager and agent, allowing the originating application to match responses with their original requests.
final_prompt:
You are analyzing a rule from the SNMP v1 protocol specification.

Rule: The value of the request-id field of the GetResponse-PDU is that of the received GetRequest-PDU message.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.3. The GetNextRequest-PDU
sentence: Upon receipt of the GetNextRequest-PDU, the receiving protocol entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object name in the variable-bindings field, that name does not lexicographically precede the name of some object available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
enhanced_sentence: When processing a GetNextRequest-PDU, if any object name in the variable-bindings field does not have a lexicographical successor within the accessible MIB view (meaning no object exists that comes after it in the naming hierarchy), the receiving entity must return a GetResponse-PDU with the error-status field set to "noSuchName" and the error-index field indicating the position of the problematic object name in the original request. This rule applies specifically when the requested object name represents the end of the MIB subtree or references a non-existent object that cannot be used to determine a valid successor for the get-next operation.
final_prompt:
You are analyzing a rule from the SNMP v1 protocol specification.
        
Context: This rule appears under the section "4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.3. The GetNextRequest-PDU"
Rule: Upon receipt of the GetNextRequest-PDU, the receiving protocol entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object name in the variable-bindings field, that name does not lexicographically precede the name of some object available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.1. Common Constructs
sentence: In these cases, ErrorIndex may provide additional information by indicating which variable in a list caused the exception.
enhanced_sentence: When an SNMPv1 agent encounters an exception while processing a request (indicated by a non-zero ErrorStatus), the ErrorIndex field must be used to identify the specific variable binding within the VarBindList that caused the failure. This applies during response generation for PDUs that operate on multiple variables, such as GetRequest, GetNextRequest, and SetRequest. The ErrorIndex value corresponds to the position (1-based index) of the problematic VarBind in the sequence, enabling the manager to pinpoint the exact variable that triggered the exception condition. This mechanism is only applicable when ErrorStatus indicates an error (non-zero) and the PDU contains multiple variable bindings.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.3. The GetNextRequest-PDU
sentence: The value of the request-id field of the GetResponse-PDU is that of the received GetNextRequest-PDU message.
enhanced_sentence: When a protocol entity successfully processes a GetNextRequest-PDU and generates a GetResponse-PDU (regardless of whether the response indicates success with noError or reports an error condition such as noSuchName, tooBig, or genErr), the request-id field in the GetResponse-PDU must exactly match the request-id value from the received GetNextRequest-PDU. This ensures proper request-response correlation between the SNMP manager and agent, allowing the originating application to associate responses with their corresponding requests. This rule applies to all GetNextRequest-PDU processing scenarios described in the protocol specification and is essential for maintaining session integrity and correct message handling.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.2. The GetRequest-PDU
sentence: (2) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object is an aggregate type (as defined in the SMI), then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
enhanced_sentence: (2) During GetRequest-PDU processing, if any object identifier in the variable-bindings field refers to an aggregate type (such as a table or row as defined in the SMI), which cannot be directly retrieved as a single value, the receiving entity must immediately terminate processing and return a GetResponse-PDU. This response shall maintain the original request-id and variable-bindings structure, but set the error-status field to "noSuchName" and the error-index field to the positional index (starting from 1) of the problematic object in the received variable-bindings list. This rule applies specifically when the receiving entity encounters aggregate object types during value retrieval operations and takes precedence over normal successful value retrieval processing.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.2. The GetRequest-PDU
sentence: Upon receipt of the GetRequest-PDU, the receiving protocol entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object's name does not exactly match the name of some object available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
enhanced_sentence: This rule governs the SNMP v1 GetRequest-PDU error handling behavior when requested objects are not accessible. It applies immediately upon receipt of a GetRequest-PDU, before any value retrieval is attempted. The prerequisite is that the receiving entity must have a defined MIB view for get operations. When this rule is triggered (specifically when any object name in the variable-bindings field does not exactly match an object available for get operations in the relevant MIB view), the receiving entity must immediately respond with a GetResponse-PDU that maintains the original request-id and structure, but sets the error-status field to "noSuchName" and the error-index field to the position (starting from 1) of the first non-matching object in the variable-bindings list. This ensures the requestor can identify which specific object caused the failure while maintaining protocol synchronization through the preserved request-id.
final_prompt:

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.2. The GetRequest-PDU
sentence: If none of the foregoing rules apply, then the receiving protocol entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU such that, for each object named in the variable- bindings field of the received message, the corresponding component of the GetResponse-PDU represents the name and value of that variable.
enhanced_sentence: This rule applies as the final step in processing a GetRequest-PDU when all preceding error conditions have been evaluated and none apply. Specifically, it governs the successful retrieval scenario where: (1) all requested object names exist in the relevant MIB view and are accessible for get operations, (2) no requested objects are aggregate types, (3) the response size does not exceed local limitations, and (4) no other retrieval errors occur. When these conditions are met, the receiving protocol entity must construct and send a GetResponse-PDU where: the variable-bindings field contains each requested object name paired with its current value, the error-status is set to noError, the error-index is zero, and the request-id matches that of the original GetRequest-PDU. This represents the normal successful execution path for GetRequest operations.
final_prompt:

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.2. The GetRequest-PDU
sentence: (3) If the size of the GetResponse-PDU generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.
enhanced_sentence: (3) When processing a valid GetRequest-PDU that has passed initial validation checks (i.e., all object names exist in the MIB view and are not aggregate types), if the size of the complete GetResponse-PDU containing all requested variable values would exceed the receiving entity's local message size limitation, then the receiving entity must immediately terminate processing and send a GetResponse-PDU to the request originator. This response must maintain the same request-id and variable-bindings structure as the original request, but with the error-status field set to "tooBig" and the error-index field set to zero, indicating that the response size constraint was exceeded before any individual variable processing could occur. This rule takes precedence over normal variable retrieval processing and ensures the protocol entity does not attempt to generate an oversized response that would violate transport layer constraints.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.1. Common Constructs
sentence: Some PDUs are concerned only with the name of a variable and not its value (e.g., the GetRequest-PDU).
enhanced_sentence: When constructing PDUs that are concerned only with variable names rather than their values (such as GetRequest-PDU), the protocol requires that the value field in each VarBind must still contain valid ASN.1 syntax and encoding, though the receiving protocol entity will ignore the actual value content. This applies during PDU construction for request operations where the intent is to retrieve or identify variables rather than set values. The expected outcome is proper protocol compliance while maintaining valid ASN.1 structure, with the recommended practice being to use ASN.1 NULL values in the value portion of such bindings. This rule applies specifically to PDUs that operate on variable names independently of their current values, and requires that all VarBind components maintain syntactically correct ASN.1 encoding regardless of semantic relevance.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.3. The GetNextRequest-PDU
sentence: (2) If the size of the GetResponse-PDU generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.
enhanced_sentence: This rule applies when a receiving SNMP entity processes a valid GetNextRequest-PDU and determines that the size of the corresponding GetResponse-PDU would exceed local implementation constraints (such as maximum PDU size limits). In this scenario, instead of generating the normal response containing the lexicographical successors of the requested objects, the entity must construct a GetResponse-PDU that mirrors the original request format but with the error-status field set to "tooBig" and the error-index field set to zero. This error response indicates to the requesting entity that the response data is too large to be transmitted, allowing the requester to potentially retry with a more targeted request. This rule takes precedence over normal response generation but is evaluated after verifying that all object names in the variable-bindings field have valid lexicographical successors in the MIB view.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.2. The GetRequest-PDU
sentence: (4) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the value of the object cannot be retrieved for reasons not covered by any of the foregoing rules, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is genErr and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
enhanced_sentence: (4) This rule serves as a catch-all error handling mechanism for GetRequest-PDU processing. It applies when all preceding error conditions (noSuchName, tooBig) have been evaluated and do not match, but the receiving entity still cannot retrieve the value of one or more objects specified in the variable-bindings field due to unspecified internal errors or conditions not covered by previous rules. When this occurs, the receiving entity must send a GetResponse-PDU that maintains the same structure and request-id as the original GetRequest-PDU, but with the error-status field set to genErr (general error) and the error-index field indicating the specific position (index) of the problematic object within the variable-bindings list. This ensures that the requesting entity receives clear error identification while maintaining protocol consistency, and this rule is only invoked after all other specific error conditions have been ruled out.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.3. The GetNextRequest-PDU
sentence: If none of the foregoing rules apply, then the receiving protocol entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU such that, for each name in the variable-bindings field of the received message, the corresponding component of the GetResponse-PDU represents the name and value of that object whose name is, in the lexicographical ordering of the names of all objects available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, the immediate successor to the value of the name field of the given component.
enhanced_sentence:
This rule governs the successful processing of a GetNextRequest-PDU when all preceding error conditions have been evaluated and do not apply. Specifically, it defines the normal case where the receiving SNMP entity must return the lexicographically next available object for each requested variable. 

The rule applies only after verifying that: (1) all requested object names lexicographically precede at least one available object in the MIB view, (2) the response size does not exceed local limitations, and (3) no general retrieval errors occur for any successor objects.

When this rule is followed, the receiving entity constructs a GetResponse-PDU where each variable-binding contains the name and value of the immediate lexicographical successor to the corresponding requested object name from the GetNextRequest-PDU. The response must have error-status set to noError, error-index set to zero, and the request-id matching the original GetNextRequest-PDU.

This enables efficient table traversal and retrieval of the next available managed objects in the MIB hierarchy according to their lexicographical ordering.
final_prompt:

Rule: If none of the foregoing rules apply, then the receiving protocol entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU such that, for each name in the variable-bindings field of the received message, the corresponding component of the GetResponse-PDU represents the name and value of that object whose name is, in the lexicographical ordering of the names of all objects available for get operations in the relevant MIB view, the immediate successor to the value of the name field of the given component.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: If none of the foregoing rules apply, then for each object named in the variable-bindings field of the received message, the corresponding value is assigned to the variable.
enhanced_sentence: If none of the preceding error conditions (noSuchName, badValue, tooBig, or genErr) are triggered during the processing of a SetRequest-PDU, then for each object specified in the variable-bindings field of the received message, the corresponding value must be assigned to the respective managed object. This assignment must be performed as an atomic operation with respect to all other variable assignments in the same SetRequest-PDU. Upon successful completion of all assignments, the receiving entity must send a GetResponse-PDU to the originator with error-status set to noError and error-index set to zero, confirming that all requested modifications have been successfully applied.
final_prompt:

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: Each variable assignment specified by the SetRequest-PDU should be effected as if simultaneously set with respect to all other assignments specified in the same message.
enhanced_sentence: When processing a valid SetRequest-PDU where none of the error conditions apply, the receiving entity must apply all variable assignments specified in the variable-bindings field as if they occur simultaneously. This atomic execution requirement ensures that either all assignments succeed together or none are applied, preventing partial updates that could leave managed objects in inconsistent states. The rule applies only after successful validation of all variable bindings against MIB view accessibility, ASN.1 type consistency, and value constraints. The expected outcome is that all target variables receive their new values in a single atomic operation, after which the entity returns a GetResponse-PDU with error-status set to noError.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: (2) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the contents of the value field does not, according to the ASN.1 language, manifest a type, length, and value that is consistent with that required for the variable, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is badValue, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name in the received message.
enhanced_sentence: This rule governs the validation of ASN.1 encoding in SetRequest-PDU operations. When a receiving SNMP entity processes a SetRequest-PDU, it must verify that for each object specified in the variable-bindings field, the value field conforms to the ASN.1 type, length, and value requirements defined for that particular MIB variable. If any object's value encoding is inconsistent with its required specification (e.g., incorrect data type, malformed length, or invalid value representation), the receiving entity must immediately terminate the set operation and return a GetResponse-PDU with error-status set to "badValue" and error-index indicating the position of the problematic object in the variable-bindings list. This validation occurs after confirming the object is available for set operations (rule 1) but before checking message size limitations (rule 3) and attempting actual value assignments.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: (3) If the size of the Get Response type message generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.
enhanced_sentence: This rule governs the handling of SetRequest-PDUs when the response message would exceed local size constraints. It applies during the processing phase after receiving a SetRequest-PDU but before attempting to execute the requested variable assignments. If the GetResponse-PDU that would be generated to report successful completion (as described in the protocol's normal processing flow) would exceed a local implementation-defined size limitation, the receiving entity must immediately send a GetResponse-PDU with error-status set to "tooBig" and error-index set to zero, without performing any of the requested set operations. This rule takes precedence over normal processing but applies only after verifying that none of the preceding error conditions (noSuchName, badValue) are present. The expected outcome is that the originator receives immediate notification of the size constraint violation, allowing it to potentially retry with a smaller request or alternative approach.
final_prompt:
You are analyzing a rule from the SNMP v1 protocol specification.
        
Context: This rule appears under the section "4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU"
Rule: (3) If the size of the Get Response type message generated as described below would exceed a local limitation, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is tooBig, and the value of the error-index field is zero.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: The receiving entity then sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form except that the value of the error-status field of the generated message is noError and the value of the error-index field is zero.
enhanced_sentence: When a receiving SNMP entity successfully processes a SetRequest-PDU without encountering any of the error conditions specified in rules (1) through (4), it must assign the specified values to all named objects as if performed simultaneously, and then send a GetResponse-PDU back to the originator. This response PDU must maintain the identical structure and request-id of the original SetRequest-PDU, but with the error-status field explicitly set to noError and the error-index field set to zero, indicating successful completion of all set operations. This rule applies only after all variable assignments have been validated and executed without errors, serving as the successful execution path in the SetRequest processing flow.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: Upon receipt of the SetRequest-PDU, the receiving entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object is not available for set operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
enhanced_sentence:
This rule governs the error handling behavior when a SetRequest-PDU is received and one or more specified objects cannot be modified due to access restrictions. The rule applies during the processing phase of a SetRequest-PDU, after the message has been received and validated for basic format compliance, but before any variable assignments are attempted. 

When this rule is triggered (specifically when an object in the variable-bindings field exists but is not writable within the current MIB view context), the receiving entity must generate a GetResponse-PDU that mirrors the original request structure, with the following modifications: the error-status field is set to "noSuchName" to indicate the object exists but cannot be set, and the error-index field contains the positional index (starting from 1) of the problematic object within the variable-bindings list. 

Prerequisites for this rule include: successful message decoding, valid PDU format verification, and confirmation that the object exists but lacks write permissions in the applicable MIB view. This rule takes precedence over actual value assignment operations and ensures the requesting entity receives clear feedback about authorization failures for specific objects.
final_prompt:

Rule: Upon receipt of the SetRequest-PDU, the receiving entity responds according to any applicable rule in the list below: (1) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the object is not available for set operations in the relevant MIB view, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is noSuchName, and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.

heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.5. The SetRequest-PDU
sentence: (4) If, for any object named in the variable-bindings field, the value of the named object cannot be altered for reasons not covered by any of the foregoing rules, then the receiving entity sends to the originator of the received message the GetResponse-PDU of identical form, except that the value of the error-status field is genErr and the value of the error-index field is the index of said object name component in the received message.
enhanced_sentence: (4) This rule applies during the processing of a SetRequest-PDU when all preceding validation checks (noSuchName, badValue, tooBig) have passed, but an attempt to modify an object's value fails due to implementation-specific constraints not covered by previous rules. Such constraints may include hardware limitations, resource unavailability, internal system errors, or other operational restrictions that prevent the write operation. When this condition occurs for any object in the variable-bindings field, the receiving entity must generate a GetResponse-PDU that mirrors the original request structure, but with the error-status field set to genErr (general error) and the error-index field indicating the position of the problematic object within the variable-bindings list. This ensures the requester receives specific feedback about which object modification failed due to these implementation-dependent reasons.
